sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• due to the risk of hypertensive crisis, the blood pressure should be well-controlled prior to starting axitinib
  • Metastatic renal cell carcinoma, First-line therapy: initial, 5 mg ORALLY twice daily; increases at 2-week intervals to 7 mg ORALLY twice daily, then 10 mg ORALLY twice daily was used in a clinical trial
  • Renal cell carcinoma, Advanced, after failure of 1 prior systemic therapy: initial dose, 5 mg ORALLY twice daily (12 hours apart) after 2 consecutive weeks based on criteria (no adverse reaction greater than grade 2, normotensive, and not receiving anti-hypertension medication); swallow whole with or without food
  • Renal cell carcinoma, Advanced, after failure of 1 prior systemic therapy: dose titration, may increase to 7 mg ORALLY every 12 hours after 2 consecutive weeks at 5 mg twice daily based on safety and tolerability criteria (no adverse reaction greater than grade 2, normotensive, and no antihypertensive medication); may increase further to 10 mg ORALLY every 12 hours after 2 consecutive weeks at 7 mg based on same safety and tolerability criteria

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy in pediatric patients have not been studied

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• hypertension: from 5 mg twice daily to 3 mg twice daily and if necessary to 2 mg twice daily for persistent hypertension despite anti-hypertensive therapy; discontinue for severe and persistent hypertension despite anti-hypertensive therapy and dose reduction; consider discontinuation for hypertensive crisis
  • bleeding requiring medical intervention; temporarily interrupt axitinib
  • surgery: interrupt axitinib for at least 24 hours prior to scheduled surgery
  • proteinuria, moderate to severe: reduce dose or temporarily interrupt axitinib
  • hepatic impairment: reduce starting dose by half in patients with baseline moderate hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh class B) and increase or decrease subsequent doses based on individual safety and tolerability; no adjustment required in patients with mild hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh class A)
  • renal impairment, mild to severe: no starting dosage adjustment required
  • elderly: no dosage adjustment required
  • concomitant use with strong CYP3A4/5 inhibitors: avoid; however, if concomitant use can not be avoided then reduce the dose of axitinib by approximately half; subsequent doses can be increased or decreased based on individual safety and tolerability; if CYP3A4/5 inhibitor is discontinued, then increase the axitinib dose used prior to initiation of the strong inhibitor after 3 to 5 half-lives of the inhibitor (strong CYP3A4/5 inhibitors include ketoconazole, itraconazole, clarithromycin, atazanavir, indinavir, nefazodone, nelfinavir, ritonavir, saquinavir, telithromycin, and voriconazole)

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Renal cell carcinoma, Advanced, after failure of 1 prior systemic therapy
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Metastatic renal cell carcinoma, First-line therapy

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Hematologic Effects:
  • -- serious and fatal thromboembolic events (ie, TIA, stroke, myocardial infarction, retinal artery or vein occlusion, pulmonary embolism, DVT) have been reported; use caution in at-risk patients
  • -- serious and fatal hemorrhage (ie, cerebral hemorrhage, hematuria, hemoptysis, lower gastrointestinal hemorrhage, melena) has been reported; treatment interruption may be required
  • Cardiovascular Effects:
  • -- heart failure, including fatalities, has occurred; monitoring recommended and discontinuation may be required
  • -- hypertension, including hypertensive crisis, has been reported; monitoring recommended and dose adjustment or discontinuation may be necessary
  • Dermatologic Effects:
  • -- wound healing complications may occur; discontinue therapy at least 24 hours before scheduled surgery
  • Endocrine/Metabolic Effects:
  • -- thyroid dysfunction (hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism) has been reported; baseline screening and monitoring recommended
  • Gastrointestinal Effects:
  • -- avoid use in patients with recent active gastrointestinal bleeding
  • -- gastrointestinal perforation and fistula formation has been reported, including 1 fatality; monitoring recommended
  • Hepatic Effects:
  • -- ALT elevations of all grades have been reported; baseline screening and monitoring (including AST and bilirubin levels) recommended
  • -- dose adjustment recommended in patients with moderate hepatic impairment (ie, Child-Pugh class B)
  • Neurologic Effects:
  • -- reversible posterior leukoencephalopathy syndrome has been reported; discontinue if condition occurs
  • -- avoid use in patients with untreated brain metastasis
  • Renal Effects:
  • -- cautiously treat patients with ESRD (CrCl less than 15 mL/min)
  • -- proteinuria has been reported; baseline screening and monitoring recommended; dose reduction or interruption may be required
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- avoid coadministration with strong CYP3A4/5 inhibitors (eg, atazanavir, clarithromycin, indinavir, itraconazole, ketoconazole, nefazodone, nelfinavir, ritonavir, saquinavir, telithromycin, voriconazole) and strong CYP3A4/5 inducers (eg, rifampin, carbamazepine, dexamethasone, phenobarbital, phenytoin, rifabutin, rifapentine, St. John's wort)
  • -- if possible, avoid coadministration with moderate CYP3A4/5 inducers (eg, bosentan, efavirenz, etravirine, modafinil, nafcillin)
  • -- avoid use with grapefruit and grapefruit juice

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Hypertension (all grades, 40%; grade 3/4, 16%)
  • Dermatologic:Hand-foot syndrome due to cytotoxic therapy (all grades, 27%; grade 3/4, 5%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Weight decreased (all grades, 25%; grade 3/4, 2%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Constipation (all grades, 20%; grade 3/4, 1%), Diarrhea (all grades, 55%; grade 3/4, 11%), Loss of appetite (all grades, 34%; grade 3/4, 5%), Nausea (all grades, 32%; grade 3/4, 3%), Vomiting (all grades, 24%; grade 3/4, 3%)
  • Hepatic:ALT/SGPT level raised (all grades, 22%; grade 3, less than 1%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (all grades, 21%; grade 3/4, 5%)
  • Other:Difficulty speaking (31%), Fatigue (all grades, 39%; grade 3/4, 11%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Heart failure (2%), Heart failure, Grade 3 or 4 (1%), Hypertensive crisis (less than 1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastrointestinal fistula (1%), Gastrointestinal perforation (up to 1%)
  • Hematologic:Arterial thrombosis (1% to 2%), Deep venous thrombosis (1%), Hemorrhage (all grades, 16%; grade 3/4, 1%), Venous thrombosis (all grades, 3%; grade 3/4, 3%)
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular accident (less than 1%), Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (less than 1%), Transient ischemic attack (1%)
  • Ophthalmic:Thrombosis of retinal vein (1%)
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary embolism (2%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Axitinib is a kinase inhibitor shown to inhibit the vascular endothelial growth factor receptors (VEGFR-1, VEGFR-2, and VEGFR-3) implicated in angiogenesis and tumor growth leading to cancer progression.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, oral: 2.5 to 4.1 hours
  • Bioavailability, Oral: 58%
  • Effect of food: a high fat, high calorie meal resulted in a 19% increase in AUC

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Liver: extensive via CYP P450 3A4/5 (CYP3A4), CYP2C19, CYP1A2, pathways, and glucuronidation
  • N-glucuronide: inactive; sulfoxide: inactive

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Renal: approximately 23%; none unchanged
  • Fecal: approximately 41%; 12% unchanged
  • Total body clearance: 38 L/hr

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• tumor regression is indicative of efficacy
  • ALT, AST, and bilirubin; prior to initiation and periodically throughout treatment
  • proteinuria; prior to initiation and periodically throughout treatment
  • thyroid function; prior to initiation and periodically throughout treatment
  • blood pressure; regularly during treatment
  • cardiac failure

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
AXITINIB
USES: Axitinib is indicated to treat advanced renal cell carcinoma after failure of one prior systemic therapy. PHARMACOLOGY: Axitinib is a kinase inhibitor shown to inhibit the vascular endothelial growth factor receptors (VEGFR-1, VEGFR-2, and VEGFR-3) implicated in angiogenesis and tumor growth leading to cancer progression. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare. TOXICITY: Dizziness, hypertension, seizures associated with hypertension, and fatal hemoptysis occurred in patients who received axitinib orally at doses up to 20 mg twice daily during clinical trials. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: The most commonly reported adverse effects include diarrhea (55%), hypertension (40%), fatigue (39%), decreased appetite (34%), nausea (32%), dysphonia (31%), hand-foot syndrome (27%), decreased weight (25%), vomiting (24%), asthenia (21%), and constipation (20%). LESS FREQUENT: Other adverse effects that have occurred less frequently include, hypothyroidism, cough, mucosal inflammation, arthralgia, stomatitis, dyspnea, abdominal pain, headache, rash, proteinuria, dysgeusia, dry skin, dyspepsia, pruritus, alopecia, and erythema.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
AXITINIB
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. For mild/moderate asymptomatic hypertension (no end organ damage), pharmacologic treatment is generally not necessary. Correct any significant fluid and/or electrolyte abnormalities in patients with severe diarrhea and/or vomiting. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. For severe hypertension with end organ effects, nitroprusside is preferred. Labetalol, nitroglycerin, and phentolamine are alternatives.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Consider activated charcoal in patients who are awake and able to maintain their airway. HOSPITAL: Consider activated charcoal after a potentially toxic ingestion and if the patient is able to maintain their airway or if the airway is protected.
  • Airway management: Intubate if patient is unable to protect their airway.
  • Antidote: None.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor serum electrolytes in patients with significant vomiting and/or diarrhea. Monitor liver enzymes and thyroid function tests. Monitor complete blood count (CBC) including differential and platelet count. Monitor for bleeding; monitor for clinical evidence of thromboembolic events. Monitor vital signs. Severe hypertension has been reported with therapeutic use and in overdose. Monitor urinalysis; proteinuria has been reported with therapeutic use. Serum axitinib concentrations are not clinically useful in guiding management following overdose, or widely available in clinical practice.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Hemodialysis is unlikely to be effective due to high protein binding (greater than 99%).
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: Asymptomatic adults with inadvertent ingestions of one or two extra doses can be monitored at home. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: All patients with deliberate self-harm ingestions, any patient who is symptomatic or ingested more than 2 extra doses, should be evaluated in a healthcare facility and monitored until symptoms resolve. Children with unintentional ingestions should be observed in a healthcare facility. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients with severe hypertension or bleeding should be admitted to the hospital. CONSULT CRITERIA: Consult with a medical toxicologist and/or poison center for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is unclear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
AXITINIB
TOXICITY: A specific toxic dose has not been established. Oral axitinib doses up to 20 mg twice daily have resulted in dizziness, hypertension, seizures associated with hypertension, and fatal hemoptysis. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: ADULT: The recommended starting dose is 5 mg orally twice daily. If tolerated, the dose may be increased up to a MAXIMUM dose of 10 mg orally twice daily. PEDIATRIC: Safety and efficacy have not been established.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patients to watch for symptoms suggestive of thromboembolic events, as arterial and venous thromboembolic events, some fatal, have been reported during treatment.
  • Instruct patient to report bleeding episodes, because the drug may increase the risk of bleeding and may cause hemorrhage.
  • Warn patient to seek immediate medical attention for persistent or severe abdominal pain, as gastrointestinal perforation and fistulas have been reported with the use of this drug.
  • Advise patient on the proper handling and disposal of chemotherapy drugs.
  • This drug may cause diarrhea, hypertension, fatigue, decreased appetite, nausea, dysphonia, hand-foot syndrome, decreased weight, vomiting, asthenia, constipation.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of reversible posterior leukoencephalopathy syndrome (headache, seizure, lethargy, confusion, blindness, other visual and neurological disturbances).
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of hypo- or hyperthyroidism. Drug may cause abnormal thyroid function.
  • Advise patient to report any unhealed wounds and inform healthcare professional if surgery is scheduled. The drug should be stopped at least 24 hours before planned surgery.
  • Patient should not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking this drug.
  • Advise patient there are multiple significant drug-drug interactions for this drug. Consult healthcare professional prior to new drug use (including over-the-counter and herbal drugs).
  • Instruct patient to take the next dose at the usual time if he/she vomits or misses a dose. An additional dose should not be taken.
